image.altText: Robyn Tremble holding a photo of her son

title.children: Robyn's son left hospital with three unexplained spinal fractures. Police gave up investigating when he died months later

image.altText: Emergency services deal with a car on fire in Penrose

items.synopsis: More and more drivers are opting for electronic vehicles over conventional cars. After two unrelated battery fires in Sydney in a week, experts say combustions are still rare.

title.children: Two electric vehicles caught fire in NSW this week, but experts say there's no cause for alarm

image.altText: Energy ratings

items.synopsis: Energy efficient appliances can save you money in the long term, but this expert says we need a bigger scheme that targets the home as a whole.

title.children: Queensland government is giving rebates for upgrading to energy efficient appliances. Is it worth it?

image.altText: An older man wearing a navy blue polo shirt leans against a pillar outside his home wearing sunglasses with his arms folded.

items.synopsis: As former Qantas workers celebrate their historic victory over the airline in the High Court, an industrial relations lawyer says any compensation bill or financial penalty won't affect Qantas' bottom line — or stop it from outsourcing jobs in the future.

image.altText: a greyhound standing in a field

image.altText: Piles of miscellaneous goods laid out on a wooden floor.

image.altText: Rescuers carry a dead body down a street with destroyed buildings on both sides

image.altText: a 10-year-old girl wearing earrings and makeup

image.altText: Michaelia Cash in front of a green background

items.synopsis: The federal Coalition will try to overturn the ACT's drug-decriminalisation policy, which reduces penalties for people possessing small amounts of illicit drugs, including cocaine, ice and heroin.

title.children: 'This is madness': Federal opposition will seek to overturn ACT's new drug laws

image.altText: A blonde male in his twenties wears a green shirt and shorts as he sits in a chair

items.synopsis: One-punch victim Danny Hodgson launches a furious broadside at WA's justice system, as it emerges the teenager convicted of attacking him has been arrested over another alleged violent crime.

title.children: 'It's a miserable life': Danny Hodgson gives up on dream of having kids as his attacker is charged with another offence

image.altText: A close up of the torso of a Coles worker in a branded polo shirt, working in a store and wearing a body camera.

items.synopsis: Coles is trialling the use of body-worn cameras to bail workers out of customer abuse.

image.altText: A person in high-vis clothes walks past large barrels in the outback.

items.synopsis: The people behind the world's biggest radio telescope being constructed in WA's Murchison region say it's a hectic but exciting time as works finally begin on the ground.

title.children: In outback Western Australia, the 'world's largest science project' is taking shape

image.altText: Back of a persons head in university graduation.

items.synopsis: Students detail consistent mishandling of sexual violence complaints as part of the biggest review of the university sector in years.

title.children: University students tell major review how the sector can better protect students from sexual violence

image.altText: A man fills his car with petrol.

items.synopsis: Surging fuel prices reignite fears about inflation as production cuts by a global oil cartel heap yet more pain on consumers at service station forecourts.

title.children: Fuel prices to stay above $2 a litre in 'bitter pill' for consumers facing fresh inflation fears

image.altText: A burnt out plastic box on the side of a brick wall outside.

items.synopsis: A spike in fires caused by DC isolators has alarmed the NT's workplace safety watchdog, as figures show most other jurisdictions are also recording fires from the devices.

title.children: Why one small component on your rooftop solar panels is causing a rise in housefires

image.altText: A woman in a floral dress and glasses, sitting on a couch looking sombre at the camera.

items.synopsis: Cheryl O'Sullivan's world was ripped apart when her daughter Karen Gilliland was murdered. Now the retiree is raising three grandchildren, and working tirelessly to help others experiencing domestic and family violence.

title.children: Karen was murdered three years ago. Now her mum is helping other women experiencing domestic violence

image.altText: A large pile of rubble, with mountains visible in the background.

items.synopsis: In the days since a deadly earthquake rippled through Morocco's High Atlas Mountain, devastating stories of loss have emerged. Seismic data and satellite imagery show the sheer scale of this destruction.

title.children: Deep in the Atlas Mountains, a monster was slowly growing. Moroccan villages on top had no chance

image.altText: Hand cradling a cup of coffee

items.synopsis: How does caffeine work in your body, how much can you have and is there a best time of the day to drink it? We explore the science behind your morning brew.

title.children: Want more 'bang for your cup?' Science says this is the best time to drink your morning brew

image.altText: An aerial image of the promenade along the Cairns esplanade with tall buildings, mud flats and the sea on either side.

items.synopsis: Tourism bosses in Queensland were dismayed Qatar Airways' request for more flights into the nation's major cities was rejected, but Cairns and Gold Coast airports hope to capitalise instead.

title.children: Queensland airports 'talking to' Qatar Airways amid international recovery

image.altText: Houses under construction in the background with building materials in the foreground

items.synopsis: Given the demand for housing across the nation, it seems a paradox that homebuilders are collapsing, but that's been the case in SA in recent months.

title.children: It's been called a 'profitless boom' — why are builders collapsing despite huge demand for homes?

image.altText: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) shortly after the opening bell in New York, U.S.

items.synopsis: The local share market has opened slightly higher following mixed results on Wall Street, Myer has posted its best annual sales result since 2005, and the jobless rate remained steady in August at 3.7 per cent. Follow live.

title.children: Unemployment rate steady at 3.7pc, Myer profits up 23pc, local shares open slightly higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Deputy chief economist at AMP, Diana Mousina, says today's unemployment data shows the Australian labour market remains resilient. She spoke to finance presenter Sue Lannin a short time ago, and says there there are signs the market is weakening. "I would say the labour market does still look quite strong across the board, however we have seen some tick-up in the unemployment rate, the unemployment rate bottomed at at 3.4%, now it's at 3.7%," she said. "The August figures are showing that underutilisation in the labour market, which is ultimately people who want to work more hours has ticked up as well a little bit. "I think that there are definitely some signs of some weakening that's going to come in the workforce, not to mention all the leading indicators of jobs growth, things like labour hiring intentions and job vacancies, they've all come down quite significantly from levels last year. "So the labour market is still going to show signs of slowing but it's taking a lot longer than most economists have been anticipating and what the RBA has been expecting as well ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Labour market looks 'quite strong across the board', economist says

children.content: , says today's unemployment data shows the Australian labour market remains resilient.
She spoke to finance presenter Sue Lannin a short time ago, and says there there are signs the market is weakening.

"I would say the labour market does still look quite strong across the board, however we have seen some tick-up in the unemployment rate, the unemployment rate bottomed at at 3.4%, now it's at 3.7%," she said.

children.content: AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Aussie dollar is up +0.2% to $US64.34 following news the unemployment rate remained steady in August at 3.7%. The All Ordinaries and ASX 200 are also up about +0.3 % (at 12.00pm AEST). BDO Economics Partner Anders Magnusson says a low unemployment rate usually indicates that things are good for households. "However, this is currently accompanied by high multiple job holdings and increasing hours worked per employee, which suggests otherwise. With costs rising more quickly than wages, Australians are working more jobs and longer hours to make ends meet." It all means there is unlikely to be further interest rate hikes from the Reserve Bank next month. Mr Magnusson says he expects inflation to continue decreasing. "Simultaneously low unemployment should be viewed by the RBA as a good thing rather than an inflation risk. Especially as wages have continued to grow by less than inflation over the last year."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aussie dollar up after jobs data

children.content: The Aussie dollar is up +0.2% to $US64.34 following news the unemployment rate remained steady in August at 3.7%.
The All Ordinaries and ASX 200 are also up about +0.3 % (at 12.00pm AEST).
BDO Economics Partner Anders Magnusson says a low unemployment rate usually indicates that things are good for households.
"However, this is currently accompanied by high multiple job holdings and increasing hours worked per employee, which suggests otherwise.
With costs rising more quickly than wages, Australians are working more jobs and longer hours to make ends meet."
unlikely to be further interest rate hikes from the Reserve Bank next month
"Simultaneously low unemployment should be viewed by the RBA as a good thing rather than an inflation risk.
Especially as wages have continued to grow by less than inflation over the last year."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The unemployment rate has remained steady at 3.7% in August. Employment has increased by 65,000 people and the number of unemployed people has dropped slightly, by around 3,000 people. ABS head of labour statistics, Bjorn Jarvis said the large increase in employment came after a small drop in July, during the school holiday period. "Looking over the past two months, the average employment growth was around 32,000 people per month, which is similar to the average growth over the past year." Hours worked fell 0.5% in August, however, it remains higher than the same time last year. "The strength in hours worked over the past year, relative to employment growth, shows the demand for labour is continuing to be met by people working mroe hours, to some extend," said Mr Jarvis.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 65,000 more employed people as unemployment rate stays steady

children.content: ABS head of labour statistics, Bjorn Jarvis said the large increase in employment came after a small drop in July, during the school holiday period.
"Looking over the past two months, the average employment growth was around 32,000 people per month, which is similar to the average growth over the past year."
Hours worked fell 0.5% in August, however, it remains higher than the same time last year.
"The strength in hours worked over the past year, relative to employment growth, shows the demand for labour is continuing to be met by people working mroe hours, to some extend," said Mr Jarvis.

image.altText: A wide shot of the front of the Supreme Court of WA with a garden bed in the foreground.

items.synopsis: A murder trial in Perth hears how a woman stabbed her close friend to death when a drunken row over how he paid for a kebab "got blown out of proportion".
